title: 112_hr992
content: The "Building American Jobs Act of 2011" is the short title of the Act, amending the 1986 Code. Any reference to an amendment or repeal in the Act is considered to be made to a section of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The table of contents for the Act is provided. The "Building American Jobs Act of 2011" includes provisions such as the extension of Build America Bonds, recovery zone bond authority, exempt-facility bonds, and tax-exempt eligibility for loans guaranteed by Federal home loan banks. It also allows for new markets tax credit against alternative minimum tax and an election for refundable low-income housing credit for 2011. The Building American Jobs Act of 2011 extends certain provisions related to bonds and tax credits until December 31, 2012. The Building American Jobs Act of 2011 extends provisions related to bonds and tax credits until December 31, 2012, amending the percentage of payments to issuers. The Building American Jobs Act of 2011 extends provisions related to bonds and tax credits until December 31, 2012, amending the applicable percentage determined in accordance with a table. The applicable percentage for qualified bonds issued during specific calendar years is as follows: 35 percent for 2009 or 2010, 32 percent for 2011, and 31 percent for 2012. The amendment allows for current refunding bonds to be considered qualified bonds under certain conditions, including having an average maturity date not later than the bonds being refunded and redeeming the refunded bond within 90 days. The amendment clarifies that for current refunding bonds to be considered qualified, the average maturity date must not exceed the refunded bonds and the refunded bond must be redeemed within 90 days. Additionally, the amendment includes capital expenditures for levees and flood control projects in the definition of qualified bonds. SEC. 3. Extension and additional allocations of recovery zone bond authority. Extension of Recovery Zone Bond Authority: The Building American Jobs Act of 2011 extends the period for Recovery Zone Bond Authority until December 31, 2011. Additionally, the allocation of 2011 Recovery Zone Bond Limitations is based on each state's 2009 unemployment numbers. The Secretary adjusts allocations to ensure each state receives a minimum percentage of national recovery zone bond limitations based on 2009 unemployment numbers. States must reallocate funds to counties and municipalities proportionally. The 2011 allocation of national recovery zone economic development bond limitations for counties and large municipalities in each state is reduced based on the 2009 unemployment numbers. States must adjust allocations to ensure a minimum percentage is received, and funds are reallocated proportionally. The 2011 national recovery zone facility bond limitation allocated to counties and large municipalities in each state can be waived. The 2011 national recovery zone facility bond limitation can be waived for counties and large municipalities. Any waived allocation can be reallocated by the State. Large municipalities in a county are treated as part of the municipality, not the county. The term '2009 unemployment number' refers to the number of unemployed individuals in a State, county, or municipality as determined by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The 2011 national recovery zone economic development bond limitation is $10 billion, while the recovery zone facility bond limitation is $15 billion. Allocations of these limitations are treated similarly for specific purposes. The 2011 national recovery zone economic development bond limitation is $10 billion, and the recovery zone facility bond limitation is $15 billion. Allocations of these limitations are treated similarly. A county or municipality can waive any allocation not used by May 1, 2011, which can then be reallocated by the State. SEC. 4. EXEMPT-FACILITY BONDS FOR SEWAGE AND WATER SUPPLY FACILITIES. Bonds for water and sewage facilities are exempt from the volume cap on private activity bonds. Amendments are made to sections 146(g) and 146(k) to allow for tax-exempt issuance by Indian Tribal Governments for water and sewage facilities. The amendments made by this section apply to obligations issued on or after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Extension of exemption from alternative minimum tax treatment for certain tax-exempt bonds. The Building American Jobs Act of 2011 temporarily amends clauses related to tax-exempt bonds issued in 2009 and 2010, extending the period until December 31, 2011. The Building American Jobs Act of 2011 temporarily amends clauses related to tax-exempt bonds, including the exclusion of tax exempt bond interest. The amendments apply to obligations issued on or after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 6. The new Markets Tax Credit can now be used against the Alternative Minimum Tax. The amendment applies to qualified equity investments made after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7 extends tax-exempt eligibility for loans guaranteed by Federal Home Loan Banks until December 31, 2011. SEC. 8 extends temporary small issuer rules for allocation of tax-exempt interest expense by financial institutions. SEC. 9 amends clauses in section 265(b)(3)(G) for years 2010 and 2011. Effective date is after December 31, 2010. The amendment allows housing credit agencies to claim a refundable credit based on their 2011 low-income housing election amount, not exceeding 85 percent of certain criteria. The amendment allows housing credit agencies to claim a refundable credit based on their 2011 low-income housing election amount, not exceeding 85 percent of certain criteria. Additionally, the State housing credit ceiling for 2011 is divided into different categories, with specific percentages allocated to each category, and coordination with non-refundable credits is required. The amendment allows housing credit agencies to claim a refundable credit based on their 2011 low-income housing election amount. The Secretary will pay the housing credit agency of each State an amount equal to the credit allowed. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to Section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code.
